description:
Dermacoccus abyssi is a species of bacterium that belongs to the Dermacoccus genus within the Micrococcaceae family. It is a Gram-positive, aerobic, and non-spore-forming coccus (spherical) bacterium.

Dermacoccus abyssi was first isolated from deep-sea sediment samples collected from the Challenger Deep, the deepest part of the Mariana Trench, located in the western Pacific Ocean. The bacterium is adapted to thrive in the high-pressure, low-temperature, and nutrient-poor environment of the deep-sea ecosystem.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequencing has shown that Dermacoccus abyssi is closely related to other Dermacoccus species, sharing significant genetic similarities. The bacterium is capable of growing at high hydrostatic pressures and low temperatures, which are characteristic adaptations to the extreme conditions found in the deep-sea environment.

Dermacoccus abyssi has the potential to be of interest in biotechnological applications, as its unique adaptations to extreme conditions may lead to the discovery of novel enzymes or metabolic pathways with industrial or pharmaceutical relevance.
